head.title: Tax Changes in the New Budget Plan: Revenue Gainers...

hedline.hl1: Tax Changes in the New Budget Plan: Revenue Gainers...

block.p: LEAD:
ENERGY
MOTOR FUELS - Gasoline, diesel, and other motor fuel taxes would increase by 5 cents per gallon on Dec. 1. The tax would rise to 10 cents on July 1, 1991. 1991: $5.4 billion 1991-95: $45 billion.
PETROLEUM PRODUCTS - tax of A 2 cents per gallon on petroleum products used as fuel would be imposed on refiners and importers starting January 1.

ENERGY
MOTOR FUELS - Gasoline, diesel, and other motor fuel taxes would increase by 5 cents per gallon on Dec. 1. The tax would rise to 10 cents on July 1, 1991. 1991: $5.4 billion 1991-95: $45 billion.
PETROLEUM PRODUCTS - tax of A 2 cents per gallon on petroleum products used as fuel would be imposed on refiners and importers starting January 1. 1991: $1.4 billion 1991-95: $12.2 billion

UNDERGROUND TANKS - One-tenth cent per gallon tax on gasoline and other transportation fuels to establish a fund for cleaning up pollution from underground storage tanks would be extended for nearly five years. 1991: $100 million 1991-95: $600 million
ALCOHOL, TOBACCO AND LUXURIES
TOBACCO - Increase excise tax on cigarettes by 4 cents per pack in 1991 and another 4 cents in 1993. 1991: $600 million !991-95: $5.9 billion.

ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES - Tax on beer would increase 16 cents per six-pack in 1991. Wine taxes would rise by 22 cents a bottle. Taxes on fifth-sized bottle of 80-proof spirits would rise 24 cents. 1991: $1.5 billion 1991-95: $10 billion

LUXURIES - A 10 percent tax would be levied on certain luxury items, applied to the amount paid over designated price thresholds in 1991. The luxury tax would apply to cars and small trucks priced over $30,000; yachts and pleasure boats over $100,000; jewelry and watches over $5,000; and furs over $5,000. 1991: $200 million 1991-95: $1.9 billion
CORPORATIONS

OZONE-DEPLETING CHEMICALS - Would impose taxes, starting January 1, on about a dozen industrial chemicals that are not currently subject to production controls under international pacts to slow the destruction of the ozone layer. 1991: $100 million. 1991-95: $500 million
SHIPPING - Taxes on cargo loaded or unloaded at American ports and on commecial ship fares would be increased. 1991: $300 million 1991-95: $1.8 billion
FOREIGN COMPANY - Tax provisions and reporting requirements applied to foreign-owned domestic companies would be tightened. 1991: $50 million or less 1991-95: $300 million
CORPORATE INTEREST - Corporations would lose their right to deduct interest paid to the I.R.S. to make up for underpayments of income tax in most cases. 1991: $1.4 billion 1991-95: $3.9 billion
AVIATION - Passenger ticket taxes would rise to 10 percent from 8 percent next year. Taxes on domestic air cargo and aviation fuel would also rise slightly. 1991: $1.3 billion 1991-95: $11.8 billion.
BUSINESS TAXES - Revisions will be made to raise $2 billion over the five-year period. 1991: $200 million 1991-95: $2 billion.
TAX DEPOSIT - Employers who collect $100,000 or more in payroll taxes daily would be required to deposit them with the Internal Revenue Service the next day. 1991: $1 billion 1991-95: $0
INSURANCE
PROPERTY LOSS DEDUCTIONS - The tax deductions property and casualty insurance companies can take for losses would be reduced. 1991: $300 million 1991-95: $1.1 billion.
ACCOUNTING - Rules governing how insurance companies account for the cost of acquiring policies would be changed, reducing certain tax deductions. 1991: $1.5 billion 1991-95: $8 billion.
TAX RETURNS
AUDITING AND COLLECTION - The Internal Revenue Service would be required to improve auditing and collection efforts. 1991: $3 billion 1991-95: $9.4 billion.

ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS - Taxpayers would have the total itemized deductions they are allowed to take reduced by 3 percent of the amount over $100,000 they report as adjusted gross income. Medical expenses and investment interest expense would not be included. 1991: $500 million 1991-95: $18 billion.
RETIREMENT, HEALTH AND AGING
SOCIAL SECURITY - State and local government employees not enrolled in a government-sponsored retirement plan would come under Social Security coverage. 1991: $2 billion 1991-95: $11.7 billion

PENSION FUNDS - Tax on money that employers transfer from their pension plans so that the funds can be used for general corporate purposes would rise to 20 percent from 15 percent. 1991: $500 million 1991-95: $1 billion

MEDICARE - State and local government employees not currently covered by Medicare would be brought into the system. As of January 1, 1992, those employees affected would have portions of their paycheck withheld to pay for their coverage. 1991: $0 1991-95: $5.2 billion
WITHHOLDING - The cap on wages subject to Federal withholding taxes to fund Medicare would rise next year to $73,000 from $51,300. 1991: $900 million 1991-95: $13 billion
Sources: Office of Management and Budget, Joint Committee on Taxation.
THE BUDGET AGREEMENT Correction: October 5, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Charts yesterday showing new tax provisions in the proposed Federal budget misstated estimates of revenue gains or losses for four categories in some copies. Corrected figures appear today on page A24.
